author: sky.cactus
content: Has there been any thought about requiring miners supply a bond with their block that is burned if their block is invalid (not properly constructed)?  Any miner could include such a block in a valid block (like uncles) and receive some small reward.

author: sky.cactus
content: The idea here is to make it so that nodes can lazily validate blocks without having to worry about DoS vectors.

author: sky.cactus
content: You would only validate that the miner signature is valid, and the miner has funds to cover the bond, then you would forward the block.

author: sky.cactus
content: If the bond is say, 3 ETH, that means a *single* invalid block propogated across the network would cost the "miner" 3 ETH.

author: sky.cactus
content: (hand waving a bit around how the miners lock up capital for this bond so they can't move it out of the way after the DoS attack)

author: sky.cactus
content: This *could* improve block propagation time across the network (because blocks propagate much faster), which would lead to lower uncle rates and can be beneficial as block size rises.

author: sky.cactus
content: Note: This would help blocks propagate faster across the network, but it would not help miners who need to fully execute parent block before they can build next-block.

author: eth2_gitter_bot
content: <jadler> This already exists. It's called Proof-of-Work. See Section 4 of the Bitcoin design paper: https://bitcoin.org/bitcoin.pdf (re @eth1x_bridge_bot: <Micah> The idea here is to make it so that nodes can lazily validate blocks without having to worry about DoS vectors.)

author: eth2_gitter_bot
content: <vbuterin> yeah, I think the block reward opportunity cost is already incentive enough to discourage publishing bad blocks

author: sky.cactus
content: Do clients currently propogate blocks as soon as they validate the work, but before they validate the block?

author: eth2_gitter_bot
content: <vbuterin> That's been happening for a while now

author: eth2_gitter_bot
content: <vbuterin> And properly implementing that was responsible for the uncle rate decrease from ~25% to ~8% in 2018-19, as I recall

author: sky.cactus
